creating_layers_in_a_photo::tip_collecti: Don't crop too tightly, get close, but capture the whole subject.
Ensure foreground objects are not too close unless you want them out of focus.
Even if you will only use one image in your story, shoot a variety of images to choose from.
Use the whole frame to tell your story. Not just the center.
When shooting multiple characters or objects, place one in the background to create a sense of depth.
Think about timing and location when trying to capture peak action.
Images on a mobile will be small. Compose with that in mind.
Get as close to your subject as possible.
Are there any distracting objects between you and subject in your frame?
Can you change your angle to include more context?
The horizon can be place on the top or bottom horizontal gridline.
Even if time is limited, make a plan, do not shoot everything you see.
Do not cut hands or faces with the edge of the frame, if possible.
Subjects in the background must not appear too small or their importance may be lost.
Repetitive actions provide the opportunity to capture the moment from different angles.
Good photography is all about light. Are you using available light as best you can?
Distracting objects in the background can ruin a well-framed foreground.
creating_layers_in_a_photo::title: Creating Layers in a Photo
creating_layers_in_a_photo::tip_collecti: Pick your moment carefully. Avoid distracting objects or people moving through your frame.
Capture a great moment, but be sure it relates clearly to your story.
Try to push the shutter button just before the intended moment, to give the camera time to react.
Remember: the viewer won't know anything about your story that you don't show them in the photograph.
"If your picture's not good enough, you're not close enough." -Robert Capa
Allow important subjects to complete inside the frame.
